instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Question
threads.message:
This poor girl, I changed her screen a few weeks ago and just came back dead.  No liquid damage.  I changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7822</TRANSISTOR> & ultrasoniced (how DF you spell that)?, But I never tested in between so I don't know which "fixed it" Anyways.  Power is back up and get a loading bar of infinity.  

Did some monkey see and doing:  [COLOR=#000000][FONT=Roboto][SIZE=13px]/sbin/mount -uw / Then type chmod 775 / [/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]  & it'll work.  But have to do that everytime? Otherwise it don't boot. Toot, toot.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Question
threads.message: Corrupted OS? Do a PRAM reset and run Diskwarrior to check filesystem.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Question
threads.message:
â€‹[USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] [USER="1"]larossmann[/USER]  Do you use diskwarrior to recover corrupted/deleted files from HDD's/SSD?

How often do you get a drive to recover files from?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Question
threads.message: UFS is for recovering deleted files. Diskwarrior is for fixing a fucked partition from improper shutdown or something.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Question
threads.message:
I'm more of the hardware guy.  I got my buddy to fix it.  He says it was fucked up partition from an update or something?  Thanx though.  I hate Apple stuff with an extreme passion.  
But I will keep this in mind and it is here in stone for others and for future reference : )  Thanks guys : )
